thread.title: Catalina, Republicans win Independence Party primary
thread.title_full: Catalina, Republicans win Independence Party primary

title: Catalina, Republicans win Independence Party primary
text:
Catalina, Republicans win Independence Party primary Matt Coyne , mcoyne@lohud.com 6:08 a.m. EDT October 12, 2015 After running a write-in campaign, the Republicans will have an additional ballot line in November. Buy Photo Peekskill Mayor Frank Catalina is up for re-election on the Republican ticket. He and the three other Republican candidates are campaigning to wrest the Independence Party endorsement from Democrats. (Photo: Tania Savayan/The Journal News) Buy Photo 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
PEEKSKILL The ballots have been counted, and the Republicans have won the Independence Party primary. 
“We knew we won on the night of the election because there were 84 or 85 votes cast," said incumbent Mayor Frank Catalina, who noted the third party endorsement was key to his 2013 victory over Mary Foster. "We knew the other ones were write-ins and, ergo, they’re there for us.” 
Catalina and the rest of the Republican slate, including Common Council candidates Brendan Fitzgerald, Herbert Reyes and Tina Fischer, sought to wrest the Independence Party line away from the Democrats since the summer, when the third party announced their endorsements. They ran a write-in campaign to do so, meaning the ballots had to be counted by hand. 
According to figures from the Westchester County Board of Elections, Fitzgerald, Reyes and Fischer won their endorsements handedly. Fitzgerald and Fischer winning 50 votes each and Reyes winning 46 to 31 for Andre Rainey and 32 each for Kathleen Talbot and Vivian McKenzie, the Democratic choices for Common Council. 
Catalina won 33 votes to Democratic challenger Ken Martin's 29. Catalina had an additional 21 votes thrown out as voters neglected to include Catalina's middle initial on their ballots. 
“The Independence Party is always important,” Catalina said. “My Independence line, I picked up, I think 224 votes (in 2013). I won by 160 votes, 162 votes. I always said without that line I don’t think I could've wont the election. 
“I expect to win by a lot more this year," he added. "I don’t think it would be such a close race.” 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://lohud.us/1Lqt788 TOP VIDEOS
